child:
Submission indicated by defeated lying with conqueror‘s
sword between teeth.
Heads of fallen enemies piled up after battle.

Heads of slain enemies displayed. Irish myth: Cross; *Icelandic:
Boberg.

Gate of captured town (castle) to be widened until
overlord’s spear can pass through crosswise.

content:
Losses
reckoned by number of stones remaining in pile after each survivor has removed
one. Irish myth: Cross.

child: Warrior not entitled to ransom if captured without arms.
Pledge with enemy to be kept.
First to reach field of combat has choice of weapons.
Warrior who begins combat has right to desist.
Choice of weapons alternates each succeeding day.

Challenger to single combat must submit to same conditions as person
challenged. Irish myth: Cross.

Warrior engaged in combat with one-armed opponent allows
one hand to be bound to his side.
Warrior disgraced by slaying of those under his protection.
Warrior dies with face toward foe.
Divorce given to wives before leaving for battle.
Challenge by turning left side of shield toward enemy.
Challenge to battle by hurling javelin skyward.

Soldiers chained (tied) together to prevent flight from
battle.
Hero drives retreating warriors back into battle.

Law requiring military service of women revoked through
influence of saint.

Retainers not required to go to battle under overlord
except for pay.

Only 700 subjects of under-king required to serve under
overlord on any one hosting.

Warriors
fight in circle around leader. Irish myth: Cross.

Superior troops distributed throughout army to prevent
their soldierly qualities from being too obvious.

content: Punishment for failure to pay tax.
child: Nose cut off for failure to pay tax.
Poet may not act as security.
Foreigner may not act as security.
“It is a debt if it is promised.”
Contract made by woman without her husband void.
He nearest to blood of slain man must avenge his death.

a legal principle applied to question of ownership of copy
of manuscript. Irish myth: Cross.

: in case of suspected illegitimacy, child is not guilty.
Irish myth: Cross.
Laws made in groups of seven. (Cf. †Z71.5.) Irish myth: Cross.
Laws made at feast every seven years.

content:
He has put the criminal to torture without success. When
he releases him, the criminal says, “In a moment I should have confessed all.”
The judge lets him go nevertheless. Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin I 266 No. 247.

child: Fool not to be punished for his crime.

content:
**R. C.
Clephan The Tournament (London, 1919); *O. Mueller Turnier und Kampf in den
altfrz. Artusromanen (Erfurt, 1907); Jewish: Neuman.
child: King is persuaded to rescind ban on tournaments.
Tournament: to avenge death of king.

content: Eric fines (imposed for personal injury, etc.).
Specified interchange of aid and gifts. Irish myth: Cross.
Taxation and payment of fines or tribute.
child:
Tribe failing to attend yearly feast to send gift as sign
of submission.

content: Criminal allowed to choose his method of execution.
child: Chooses to die of old age.

Criminal given choice of
deaths. (Cf. †J1181.) Hdwb. d. Märchens s.v. “Friedrich
der Grosse” n. 58.

Man condemned to lose his eye is allowed to choose the
instrument.

Herbert III 71; Hervieux IV 310
No. 117; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

content:
Criminal may fight against odds rather than be judicially
executed.
Condemned woman may be freed by marrying a rogue.

*Fb “gifte” I 432; Zs. f. Vksk. XXIII 108, XXV 286, XXVII 236; Sehreuer Zs.
f. vgl. Rechtswiss. XXXIV 201; Blätter f. pommersche Volkskunde VII 63.
child:
Release from execution at a woman’s request (by marriage to
her).

content: Pardoning of criminal comes too late.
Crime less serious if committed at request of a lady.
Youngest of judges first to give decision.

child:
Two friends captured by Moors have money to ransom only
one.

The ransomed one returns home, gets
money and buys the other‘s freedom. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Man who has counseled friend in assassination asks to be
killed on the other’s body.
Friend‘s intercession saves man from execution.

Man is abducted by pirates and kept in slavery forty years. Upon his return his
friend divides his earnings with him. Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

Hands of friends extend through sides of tombs and clasp in
death.
Successful rival gives his lady to unsuccessful friend.

Friends bind themselves each to grant every desire of the
other. Irish myth: Cross.
Danger of one saint voluntarily incurred by another.

content: Man refuses to follow friend in wicked conduct.

Scala Celi 11a No. 66; Alphabet No. 56; Italian Novella:
Rotunda.
Sitting in a circle of feasts.

Friends bound in brotherhood through partaking of milk from the
same woman. *Cosquin Études 247ff.; Wiedemann Am Urquell III 259ff.
child: Friendship starts at babyhood: two babies exchanged.

content:
Friends take oath of brotherhood by means of mixing their blood. *Type 1364;
**Encyc. Rel. Ethics II 717a, 857ff.; **H. C. Trumbull The Blood Covenant
(London, 1887); *Chauvin VII 20 No. 373D; *Hibbard 145 n. 3; Fb “blod” IV 46b;
Nitze MPh IX 291; DeVries Acta Philologica Scandinavica III 106; *Basset RTP VI
577--XXV 438 passim; *Julian Revue d’Ethnographie et de Trad. Pop. II 1ff.; **H. Tegnæus Blood-Brothers
(Stockholm, 1952). -- Irish myth: Cross: Icelandic: *Boberg; Tuamotu: Stimson
MS (z-G 13/203); Africa: Stanley 274.
child: Saint makes blood covenant with animals.

Drinking mixture of blood, milk, and wine as pledge of
covenant.
Sworn brethren and blood brethren avenge each other.

Surviving blood brother to watch three nights in
grave-mound.

Icelandic: Egils saga ok
Asm., Lagerholm 28 (cf. introd. xxiv--xxix).

content:
Friends take an oath of lasting brotherhood. *Type 516; Rösch FFC
LXXVII 98; *Hibbard 68 n. 7, 145 n. 3; Child IV 146f.; Wesselski Märchen 187
No. 2; *Krappe Bulletin Hispanique XXXIX 17; *Abeles “Die Burgschaft als Motif in der jüdischen Literatur” Monatsch. f. Geschichte u. Wissenschaft der Juden LX
213ff., 263ff. -- English: Wells 158 (Amis and Amiloun); Icelandic: Olrik
Sakses Oldhistorie I (1892) 59ff., *Boberg; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; Jewish:
*Neuman, bin Gorion Born Judas@2 IV 14, 20, 274; India: Thompson-Balys; Korean:
Zong in-Sob 63 No. 35.
child: Friends take oath of brotherhood by exchanging flowers. India: Thompson-Balys.

Human sons of animal companions go together on adventures
Africa.
Saints exchange bachalls as mark of affection.
Friendship between a prince and common man.
Friends want to divide good and evil.
Dying hero sends greetings to friends.
Friends want their children to be friends too.

Dying man asks friends to let his son inherit his
friendship together with his father’s weapons.
One friend dies shortly after the other.
Man wins wife for his friend.

Friends given the power of reading each other’s secret
thoughts.

content:
Refusal to receive preferred help until series of stories
has been told.
Friend sacrifices his life for the other.
child:
Man knowing of murder plot against his friend disguises and
is killed in his place.
(Cf. †P361.1.) Scala Celi 9b No. 61; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

content: Friends offer to die for each other.

(Bürgschaft.) Each
falsely confesses crime so as to save the other. Neither guilty. Often combined
with †P325. **Abeles “Die Bürgschaft als Motif
in der jüdischen Literatur” Monatschr. f. Geschichte
u. Wissenschaft der Juden LX 213ff., 263ff.; **K. Kelling Das Bürgschaftsmotiv
in der französischen Literatur (Leipzig diss., 1915); *Chauvin III 124 No. 113,
V 215f., VIII 194ff. IX 16f.; *Hdwb. d. Märchens I 350a s.v. “Bürgschaft”; Köhler-Bolte II 557,
580f.; Gaster Exempla Nos. 362, 419; Basset 1001 Contes II 293ff.; Boccaccio
Decameron X No. 8 (*Lee 330); Fischer Zs. f. deutsche Morgenländische Ges.
LXXII 290; Bolte Zs. f. Vksk. XXI 193 n. 4, 194; Scala Celi 10a, 11b Nos. 62,
68; bin Gorion Born Judas IV 20, 274; Alphabet Nos. 53, 57. -- Spanish Exempla:
Keller; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
child: Competition in friendship: prisoner and jailor.

Officer in charge of prison offers to let his friend
escape, though his own life will be forfeited. The friend refuses; tells
officer to let king think he has escaped and if the king demands his life the
officer can produce the prisoner. King hears of the generosity and forgives the
prisoner. Chauvin V I No. 1.
Friend gives false witness to set free his accused friend.

content:
Porcupine asks rabbit for hospitality. When rabbit
complains of being pricked, porcupine tells him to leave if he does not like
it. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Murderer of a man’s father takes refuge in his house and is saved by him.
*Chauvin II 198 No. 31.
child:
Nobleman forces escaping prisoner to accept his
hospitality.

Intercedes for his pardon.
Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Guest in disguise or under false name.

Refugee entertained in holy place (church, monastery,
etc.).

content: Hosts refrain from telling guest of death in household.

Wesselski Archiv
Orientální II 431; Greek: Euripides Alcestis.
Eating a man‘s salt creates mutual obligation. *Chauvin VI 196 No. 368.

Host
places imaginary feast before guest, who accepts it in the same spirit. Guest‘s
courtesy is rewarded by real feast. *Chauvin V 163 No. 86; Arabian: Burton
Nights I 317.
Student enters competition with his master.
child:
Is overcome by the latter‘s tricks. Italian Novella:
*Rotunda.

content: Shabby hospitality forces guests to leave.

Master demands that servant tell him of his faults as well
as of his good qualities.

If host does not return, the house shall belong to the
guest.

So declares the host as he departs
on a mission for the guest. *Chauvin V 209 No. 120 n. 1; Japanese: Ikeda.

Strangers entertained by family to whose hitching-ring they
happen to tie their horses.

Thus confusion
avoided as to where strangers are to be entertained. Italian: L. de Francia
Novellino (Torino, 1930), Rotunda.

child: Faithless men-servants corrupt the maids in the household.
Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 209; Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Servant planning to possess his master’s goods.
Has already possessed his wife. Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 613.

content:
Faithful servant entrusted with care and education of crown
prince.

King demands work, sport or entertainment from winter
guests.
child:
Christian king makes baptism a condition for hospitality
during the winter.

content: Teacher dies of pride over success of pupil.
Poor person makes great effort to entertain guests.
child:
Poor host and his wife kill themselves because they are
unable to entertain expected guests.

Wife scolds husband‘s hospitality, as he really has nothing
to give.

Poor peasant closes the eyes in order not to see guest eat:
later suicide.

content: English romance: Malory passim; Icelandic: Boberg.
child: Host treats guest with food and everything possible.

content: Refusal to believe that a friend has spoken ill of one.
child: Refusal to believe that a friend will harm one.

Alexander drinks cup said to have been poisoned by his
friend. Spanish Exempla: Keller.

content: Teacher threatens to curse pupils if they disobey.
Host surrenders his wife to his guest.

The guest unwittingly
falls in love with the wife. The host, on being informed, out of pure
generosity repudiates the wife and has her marry the guest. (Often joined with
†P315.) Chauvin V 136 No. 64; also references to †P315; Spanish Exempla:
Keller.
child: Guest begets son with his host’s daughter.

content:
*Types 516; *BP I 46; **Rösch FFC LXXVII 95f.; **Hdwb. d.
Märchens I 389 (and cross references there given); Icelandic: *Boberg; Spanish
Exempla: Keller; Jewish: *Neuman; India: Thompson-Balys; Korean: Zong in-Sob
154ff. No. 68.
child: Faithful servant dies for his master.

Puts on his master‘s clothes so as to be slain in his place. (Cf. †P316.) Alphabet
No. 327; Japanese: Ikeda.

Faithful servant kills his master‘s murderer and is killed
in turn.

Faithful servant wants to follow on dangerous quest, where
he alone is killed.
Hero’s charioteer faithful to master till death.

Faithful servant remains at home and fights for exiled
hero.
Faithful servant sacrifices sons to save life of king.

Sons resuscitated and servant enriched. Penzer IV 177f.,
VI 272f.; India: Thompson-Balys.

Faithful nurse tries to save tyrant’s daughter by exposing
her own in her place.
Abandoned maiden helped by her faithful nurse.
Faithful servant dies avenging master‘s death.
Captain will not betray king’s secret.

He refuses to betray where recruits are being raised.
Spanish: Childers.
Faithful servant undergoes torture for sake of his master.
Crow lets itself be caught so as to save king of crows.

content:
Noble person saves self from difficulties by knowledge of a
trade.

child: King and vassals: obligations of vassals to king.
King demands open gate to vassals‘ castle (city).

content:
Noble woman given to foreigners on condition that
thereafter their land be held by female right.

child: Knight’s duty to perform as lady bids.

content:
Queen must pay tribute to victorious queen to the amount
paid by king to victorious king.

child:
Queen commits suicide, as her husband vanquishes and kills
her father and her brother.
King sits mourning on his wife’s grave mound.

King mourns so much at wife‘s death that he goes on piracy,
(every summer afterward).

King calls daughter in second marriage by the name of his
first queen.

Greek: Odyssey VI 313; Jewish: Neuman; India:
Thompson-Balys.

content:
Queen marries
murderer of her fiancée.
child:
Queen leaves country with her son, having killed her
husband in revenge for his killing of her father and brother.

content:
Queen persuades king to make war without cause that her
sons may have territory.
child: Queen persuades husband to riot against his superior.

Queen persuades husband to claim her father’s kingdom after
his death.
Queen persuades husband to avenge her father.

Queen offers son to be killed in order to spur to fight and
avenge her first husband.

Chieftainess of such rank that none of her countrymen can
woo her.
No king to rule who is not husband of certain queen.
Queen commits adultery with husband’s foster son.
Queen (princess) pours liquor for battle champions.

content:
Princess cannot be married to someone of low caste, though
he passes suitor test.
child:
Great warrior destroyed by king when he asks for princess
in marriage.

content:
Issue of marriage of brother and sister of highest chiefly
rank is a god.

Prince forfeits father’s and God‘s blessing if he fails to
claim throne.

Certain foods, ornaments, feathers, etc. reserved for
royalty.
Impossible to refuse the request of a troubled nobleman.
Garment must be removed in presence of certain high chiefs.

child: Prophecy that brother who first kisses saint will be king.
Choice of kings by divine will.

*Egerton JAOS XXXIII 158; Krappe Revue Hispanique LVI
(1922) 5--24; *Penzer V 175ff.; *Chauvin VI 75 No. 239; India: Thompson-Balys.
Winner of contest to be king.

King chosen by contest: princes finding greatest fault with
their father.

Youngest can find no fault
and is chosen. Type 924**.

The one of two giant brothers who performs the greatest
feat and procures the wildest dog elected as king.

The one of two giant brothers who gets the most skillful
princess elected as king.
Owner of magic object chosen as king.
King chosen on basis of strength and exploits.
Irish myth: Cross; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
He who can open palace door to be king.
Amasser of largest fortune to be king.
He who can fill out a certain wide seat chosen as king.
Inauguration of king as espousal to goddess.
Special place where occur births of royalty.
Mismanagement of king’s treasury a mortal offense.
Royal purple (golden diadem) worn as sign of royalty.
Kingly insignia worn only on field of battle.
Ring can make or unmake a king.
Custom to appoint a king by day and slay him at night.
King must never be present at funeral.
King has first choice in booty.
Fifth of the land‘s production belongs to king.

Penzer II 127; Irish myth: *Cross; Icelandic: Boberg;
India: Thompson-Balys.
Attackers flee into exile. Irish myth: Cross.
Good king never retreats in battle.
Dead king carried into battle in his war-chariot.
King in battle hides in ditch, with earth piled around him.
Just king brings good fortune upon people.

Four duties of king to subjects: devotion, protection of
subjects, justice, and increase of his kingdom.
Clever king knows everything in advance.
King banishes nobleman whose castle he wants.
Nobility of character a mark of kings.

Kings overcomes passion for beautiful captives and sends
them back untouched to their people. Spanish Exempla: Keller.

King is superior to all in strength, beauty, largeness,
etc., and usually has victory.
King to be seen after anger cools.

Beaten because he does not get up early enough. (King
Alfred and the cakes.) *BP III 451 n. 1.
Disguised king taught courtesy by peasant.
English: Wells 94 (The Taill of Rauf Coilyear).

King pardons person who has made mistake of addressing one
of his courtiers as king.
King demands subject’s wife for himself.
King carries off subject’s wife and makes her his own.
King loses his kingdom to impostor.

King is cursed by disguised dwarf-smiths whose work he
criticised.
King frees man sent by rival king to kill him.

He sees bravery in the would-be assassin. Spanish Exempla:
Keller.

King descends to bottom of sea in glass barrel to study
ways of fishes.

King himself works at brick building so that subjects
cannot complain of enforced labor.

Subjects drive their ruler away after he has made them do
forced labor.
Prisoners released as celebration of king’s success.
King will not permit a one-eyed man in his presence.
King playing chess when important news arrives.
King orders all gold brought to him.
King never touches earth: carried always by slaves.

He sulks here until his wishes are carried out. India:
*Thompson-Balys.

None permitted to enter hall of king unless he possesses an
art.

King does not want men who are unable to engage in any
sport.

King asks all newcomers what they can do and expects a
prompt answer.
Law that nobody may give the king bad tidings.

King angry at hero who rides straight into the castle
without permission.
King has his own gifts stolen back for him.
King gives his own wife as reward.

King requires everyone who comes before him to tell a
story.
King has champion to enforce respect.

one third dedicated to watching boys at play; one third to
playing fidehell (chess?); one third to drinking. Irish myth: Cross.

King orders man whose neck the rope will fit to be
executed.
King goes in disguise at night to observe his subjects.
Tom-tom beater to spread the news of kingship.
King shows himself in public only one day a year.
King keeps lions as pets and a lion-tamer at his palace.

King does not eat much during years of famine in order not
to forget the hungry.
No sons left to rule after father.

Lawmaker’s sons slain in rebellion against him. Irish
myth: Cross.
At son‘s wedding king names him as successor.

Vengeance for destruction of fairy-mound pursues king’s
descendants.
First man to arrive after king‘s death to be heir.

(Cf. †N683.) Hdwb. d.
Märchens I 605a n. 62; India: *Thompson-Balys.

Queen chosen to live rather than king so that she can bear
an heir to the throne.

Serpents alleged to
tell by their death which shall die first: male serpent predicts king’s death;
female, queen‘s. King has male serpent killed. BP IV 139; Gesta Romanorum No.
92.

Second-born son declared as successor because message about
the birth of first son was slower traveling.
Emperor will not change proclamation. India: Thompson-Balys.
Succession will fall to line that has been wronged.

(Cf. †P17.10.) Irish
myth: Cross; Icelandic: Boberg; Jewish: Neuman.
Natural son succeeds to the throne.
Natural son is refused kingship and half heritage.

Three sons each get a kingship, but the youngest the most
important in the home country.
Slayer of king marries widow and inherits kingdom.

King to be succeeded by whoever can carry his dead body a
certain distance.

What the princes most desire: king asks each of three sons
separately.

Answers: to study, to make
pilgrimages, to build a great kingdom. Last chosen. India: Thompson-Balys.

King (prince) retires from the world (becomes hermit,
swineherd).

*Chauvin VI 194 No. 363; Irish
myth: Cross; Icelandic: *Boberg.
King on retiring orders funeral obsequies given him.
King learning of queen‘s adultery abdicates.

The higher the office held in this world, the heavier the
judgment of God: Cuchulinn’s reason for abjuring kingship.
Father abdicates in favor of son.
King must resign if he begets natural son.
Attempt to kill old king by suffocating him in bathroom.
King too old to fight goes himself into his grave mound.

*Wesselski Märchen 230;
Icelandic: Corpus Poeticum Boreale I 303, *Boberg.
Shavings of spear which killed king cast into cataract.

King slain by “his own household” in revenge for deposing
his father.

Land where every raja dies; if he rules for a day he dies
that night; if he rules for a night, he dies that day.

All children born in realm on same day as chief‘s son are
brought to palace to be the boy’s companions.

content: Birth rites confer royalty on infant prince.
Dispossessed prince taunted by usurper‘s son.
West Africa: Frobenius Atlantis VI 182ff. No. 4.
Unknown prince chosen chief of children in play.
Prince imprisoned as hostage for safety from king.

child: King’s presence necessary for army‘s victory.

King may have any woman as paramour if he makes her a
settlement.
King abducts woman to be his paramour.

King must procure whatever visiting poets ask, or suffer
from their satire.

King may judge against all save one of highest rank in
religion or learning.
King raised from dead (by saint). Irish myth: Cross.

After highly mourned wife‘s death the king marries another
who turns out to be an evil witch.
Limited number of wives for polygamous king.

content:
Types 327, 700; Köhler Aufsätze 49; Sébillot Métiers No. 16;
Missouri French: Carrière.

Type 326; German Grimm
No. 4; *Hdwb. d. Abergl. IX Nachträge 269f.; Sébillot Métiers No. 8.

**C. Nyrop Dania VIII 195ff.; *Sébillot Métiers No. 10; Irish
myth: Cross; Spanish: Espinosa Jr. Nos. 151, 155--157, 185.
child:
A shoemaker spits at Christ on way to be crucified. Christ
tells him, “A poor slobbering fellow thou shalt be, and all shoemakers after
thee, for what thou has done to me.” (Cf. †A2231.2, †P445.1.) England; Baughman.

content:
Sébillot Métiers No. 13; Panchatantra (tr. Ryder) 62ff., 89ff.,
260ff.; Irish myth: Cross; Jewish: Neuman.

child:
Always transports passengers and when the ruler is in danger
takes his place. (Cf. †Q25.) Cosquin Lorraine I 215.

Ferryman puts oar into king’s hand and he must remain
ferryman.

content: Son insists on following father‘s trade.

This has been kept secret at request of dying father who
was unsuccessful. Son learns from mother. *Cosquin Contes indiens 395ff.

child: Tongue of dead lawyer found to be lacking.
Scala Celi 7b No. 44; Etienne de Bourbon No. 440.
Scribe who cannot read his own writing.

content:
Penzer X
263a s.v. “Physician”; Irish myth: Cross.
child: Physician hides eyes as he passes graveyard.

He does not want to see those who have died from his
medicine. *Wesselski Hodscha Nasreddin I 259 No. 204.
Doctor who can cure can also poison.

This reflection brings the doctor under the king’s
suspicion. *Chauvin V 276 No. 156.

“Skillful” physician compelled to help carry away the bier
of his dead patient.

content: Irish myth: Cross; Icelandic: MacCulloch Eddic 311.
child: Druid inspires great respect and fear.
Person assailed by druid loses treasure.
Fear of druidic lampoon as activating power.

Wounded soldiers healed by bath in pool of milk through
power of druid.
In fear of clerics pagans flee into fairy mounds.
First of animals and fruits belong to priest.

Hdwb. d. Märchens I 507b; Irish myth: Cross; Spanish: Espinosa II
No. 75, Espinosa Jr. No. 186.

Untrained monk becomes skillful wright (smith) through
power of saint.
Woman disguised as monk enters monastery.

content:
Type 461 (Danish); Von Sydow Våra folksagor (1941) 38; *Sébillot
Métiers No. 1; Missouri French: Carrière; Spanish: Espinosa Jr. Nos. 137, 141,
198.

*Fb “skrædder”; *Chauvin IX 29 No. 18; *Sébillot Métiers No. 7; *Feilberg Dania
I 165ff., III 184ff.; Paludan Danske Studier (1925) 19ff.; Missouri French:
Carrière.
child: Tailor occupies God’s throne for a day.
Tailoring only trade devil cannot learn.

He fails to knot thread because it would make sign of the
cross. Scotch: Campbell Superstitions 304.
Busy tailor asks soldier to mount watch in his place.

content:
*Sébillot Métiers Nos. 17, 18; *Hdwb. d. Abergl. IX Nachträge
257--67; Andree (1878) 153; *Nyrop Dania IX 186ff.; Von Sydow Våra folksagor
(1941) 39ff. -- Irish myth: Cross; Icelandic: *Boberg; Missouri French:
Carrière; Jewish: *Neuman.
child: Smith as lord of hall of hospitality.
Smith honored by king as indispensable.
Why weavers are the most unhappy of men.

They gave a nail for the Crucifixion. Flemish: DeMeyer FFC
XXXVII 84 No. 27C.

content: Sébillot Métiers No. 11; Penzer III 100 n. 1.
*Hdwb. d. Abergl. IX Nachträge 485ff.; Missouri French: Carrière.
child:
Soldier who has had both hands severed fights with his
teeth until he is killed.
Soldier dies happy on learning of enemy‘s rout.
Soldier is ordered to set fire to enemy’s armada.
Is caught and sawed in two. Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Woman instructs in art of arms.
Brave soldier and timid cabinet-maker as companions.

content:
Penzer X
77a s.v. “Astrologer”; Jewish: *Neuman; India: Thompson-Balys.

child: Peasant refuses to sell possessions to king.

(Miller of Sanssouci.) Swiss: Jegerlehner Oberwallis 309
No. 13.

Peasant and his wife in hut near castle as contrasts to
king and queen.

Peasant is cutting wood in front of his house as guests
arrive.
Wounded hero finds shelter and is cured in peasant‘s house.

Hero stays overnight in peasant’s house, to which he
accidentally comes, and where he gets advice and direction.
Life of shepherd proper preparation for ruler.

content: Irish myth: Cross; Missouri French: Carrière; Jewish: *Neuman.

child:
Wealthy usurer prays that the sons of the rich will become
mad.

That will benefit his business. His
own sons lose their minds. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

He does so, not because it is wrong, but because he is
losing money. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

content: Wife only one able to persuade her husband.
Wife drinks blood of slain husband.
child: Wife commits suicide (dies) on death of husband.

content: Wife more merciful than blood relations.

They refuse to ransom condemned man; wife does so. Child
II 349f., III 516, IV 481, V 231ff., 296.
Husband more merciful than blood relations.

They refuse to ransom condemned woman; husband does so.
Child II 346--53, III 511, IV 481f., V 231ff., 296.
Wife chooses father’s side in feud.

Must choose between husband and father. S. A. Indian
(Carib): Alexander Lat. Am. 266.
child: Wife chooses father rather than husband or son.

(Cf. †P253.3.) Only one
can be saved; he alone is irreplaceable. Spanish: Childers.
Mother kills husband for murdering their daughter.
Foster parents fined for blemish on child.

Peasant and his wife as foster parents of exposed king‘s
son.
Parents kill son for slaying their foster son.

content:
**C. Schubert Der Pflegesohn (Nourri) im Heldenepos (Marburg,
1906); Irish myth: Cross; Missouri French: Carrière.
child:
(Cf. †N845.) English
romance: Malory, Book 1; Icelandic: Boberg.

Living king’s or nobleman‘s son as foster son of father’s
friend: considered an honor for the foster father.

Foster children return foster father’s love: avenge him,
etc.
King‘s son named after his father’s foster father.

Thor slays his foster father and takes himself the realm of
Thrace.

Icelandic: Snorra Edda Prol. III,
MacCulloch Eddic. 314.

content: Irish myth: Cross; Missouri French: Carrière.
child: Former mistress as sons’ foster mother.

content:
*Valtyr Gudmundsson “Fóstbrædralag” in prjár Ritgjörethir
(Kaupmannahöfn, 1892) 29--55; Irish myth: Cross; Icelandic: *Boberg.
child:
*Type 516; *BP I 46; *Rösch FFC LXXVII 96;
Irish myth: Cross; Icelandic: *Boberg.
King‘s son begs pardon for treacherous foster brother.

Promise of marriage to king’s daughter induces warrior to
fight foster brother.

Earl‘s son seduces foster brother’s sister and betrays
himself.

King‘s son falsely accuses foster brother of attempt to
seduce his sister.
Magic writing makes foster brothers enemies.
Unable to hit man himself, enemy kills his foster brother.
Children of Tuatha De Danann fostered by Milesians.
Love between foster sister and foster brother.
Foster son commits adultery with foster father’s wife.

content: Irish myth: Cross; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
child:
Daughter marries her husband’s slayer in order to save her
old father from war.
Father and daughter die at same time.

content: Type 450; Irish myth: Cross; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
child: One sister and six (seven, eleven, twelve) brothers.
Brother about to drink blood of seemingly guilty sister.

East Africa: Zuure L’Ame du Murundi (Paris, 1932) 331ff.
No. 2.
Brother chosen rather than husband or son.

Only one can be saved;
he alone is irreplaceable. Chauvin II 190 No. 2; Tawney Journal of Philology
XII 121; Aly Volksmärchen bei Herodot 35, 109; Philippine: Fansler MAFLS XII
257 No. 31.
Girl comes to brother‘s aid when he is attacked.

She slays the assailant and is eventually acquitted.
Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Brothers persecute sister‘s lover and are in return killed
by him.
Clever sister saves life of brother.
Woman dies of sorrow for death of brother.

content:
*Penzer III
272 n. 1; Irish myth: Cross; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
child:
Brought to test by actions at apparent death of hero.
India: Thompson-Balys.
Warrior will not fight where his brother was slain.
Place considered defiled. Irish myth: Cross.
Brothers follow each other in exile.
Brothers strive to avenge each other.

Brothers kill brother because they fail to understand his
wise answer.
Two brothers follow and help each other on piracy, etc.
Two brothers are confusingly like each other.
Man’s descendants shall serve those of his brother.

Older brother has birthright, entitling him to a double
share.

Repudiation of relationship of birth between man and his
bad brother.
Mother dislikes her children in forced marriage.

Queen dislikes son who is unlike her and loves a poor girl:
plots against him.

Folly of father’s giving all property to children before
his death.

They abandon him. *Oesterley
No. 273; Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 116 No. 980A. Cf. Shakespeare‘s King Lear.

Supposed chest of gold induces children to care for aged
father.

They think that the chest of stones contains the inheritance. *Pauli (ed.
Bolte) No. 435; Scala Celi 98b No. 528; Dunlop-Wilson II 185f.; von der Hagen
II lviii No. 49; Hdwb. d. Abergl. IV 1290. --Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 2452*;
Spanish: Boggs FFC XC 116 No. 980A; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; Palestine:
Schmidt-Kahle Volkserzählungen aus Palästina II No. 123; India:
*Thompson-Balys; Indonesia: Jeynball Catalogus Maleische en Sundaneesche Hss.
173, ibid. Supplement Catalogus Javaansche en Madoereesche Hss. 22.

Not daring to curse father directly, son does so
indirectly.
Son deposes father and usurps throne.

Undutiful children ridicule father while he is drunk and
naked.
Undutiful son overawes his father by threats.

Undutiful son taught lesson showing his mother has suffered
from him.

Wicked mother and her sons do everything to prevent
daughter‘s marriage with beloved.

Mother lets daughter unwittingly marry own father in order
to avenge his raping.

content:
Irish
myth: Cross; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
child: Son as pledge for father who has committed murder.
Young hero rebuked by his father.
Father drives away bad son whom the mother prefers.

Berserks scold their father who apparently without reason
called their adversary invincible.

Hero’s son by giantess scorns his father‘s feebleness:
still it is the son who is slain.
Oldest son responsible to father for welfare of others.

English romance: Malory X 21, 34, 36; Icelandic: *Boberg; Jewish: Neuman;
India: Thompson-Balys; Africa: Bouveignes 163.

Son must threaten father before he will recognize him as son,
even though he brings ring from his mother.
Son chastizes father for scorning mother.

Father in vision reproves son about to succumb to
temptation.

Birthright transferred by father from the oldest son to
another.
Boy sickens from grief at mother‘s death.

Mother kills sons who lack courage to help her revenge her
father and brothers, and are likely to betray the plot.

Mother reveals fact that son is offspring of supernatural
father.

Mother (eagle) casts out dull, stupid changeling; rears
bold, energetic son.

Mother commits suicide when son wants to marry foreigner
according to foreign rites.

content: Irish myth: Cross; Missouri French: Carrière.
child: Realm ruled by stepmother, while king is absent.
Stepmother mourns her stepsons’ death, not her own son‘s.

(Cf. †T418.) Irish myth:
Cross; Greek: Euripides Hippolytus; Chinese-Persian: *Coyajee JPASB XXIV 192.
Love of stepmother who has killed her husband refused.

content: Inherent enmity between members of a family.
child: Feud between two branches of family.

content:
A boy interrupts a game played with the bones of his
father or other murdered relative. N. A. Indian: Kroeber JAFL XXI 225.
Person reproached for having no relatives.
Irish myth: Cross; Koryak: *Jochelson JE VI 372.

child: Bad relations between mother-in-law and daughter-in-law.

content: Parents descend to hell instead of sons.
child: Pious children save their parents from hell.

Idle sons-in-law driven away by gradually reducing their
food.

Hdwb. d. Abergl. III 803; Missouri French: Carrière. See also
†N811 and all references and cross-references.

content:
*F. B. Gummere
The Sister’s Son (Oxford, 1901); C. H. Bell The Sister‘s Son in the Mediaeval
German Epic (Berkeley, 1922); Irish myth: Cross.

*Rivers “The
Father‘s Sister in Oceania” FL XXI 42.
child: N. A. Indian (California): Gayton and Newman 82.
Children take after their mother’s brothers.
Hero killed in fighting with father‘s brother.
Young prince sent to his father’s mother‘s brother.

content: Irish myth: Cross; Missouri French: Carrière.

Man so rich that people prefer the dung from his mules over
king‘s gold and silver.

child: Fool makes friends with birds and beasts.

Customary to shave heads of demented so that they may be
recognized as such.
Fool recognized by lump on his forehead.

content:
Minister acts as stepping-stone in midst of flame-filled
trench so that king can step across from one side to the other.
Banished minister found indispensable and recalled.

child: Knocking out a slave‘s tooth entitles him to freedom.

content: Children of slave and free person become slaves.

child: Captives from battle sold as slaves.

Futile attempt to get rid of man by selling him to
merchants as slave.

content:
Requirement that slaves given as tribute should not know
Irish.
Branding person makes him one’s slave for life.
child: Bond woman with rope girding her loins.
Female slaves as medium of exchange (unit of value).

content: Beggar rewarded by king for poem (song).

child:
**Goebel Jüdische Motive in märchenhafte Erzählungsgut (Gleiwitz,
1932) 281--288; Jewish: *Neuman.

content:
Irish
myth: Cross; Spanish Exempla: Keller.
child: Wolves of his own country dearer than dogs of another.

Mother of invalided soldier says of his limping: “Every
step will remind you of your virtue.”
Common citizen saves the honor of his country.
Gives his own funds. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Scipio plunges into burning pit to save Rome from
destruction.

Kills another by mistake. Burns off his hand for having failed.
Italian Novella: Rotunda.

National unity preserved by expulsion of all foreign
elements.

Aristotle rises from sick bed to rush into battle for his
country.
Aversion to burial in foreign soil.

Patriotism: king learning that nation will triumph whose
king dies in battle, allows self to be killed.
Clerics fast against God for revelation.
Fasting by saints causes tree worshipped by pagans to fall.
Calves not let to cows during fast.

content:
Servant must keep horns and hide of his cattle that are
slain.
Bridle goes with horse when horse is bought.
Hut for invalid to prevent noxious odor.
Pulling out hair as sign of grief.
child: Tearing garments as sign of grief.

content: Old person commits suicide when strength fails.

Charon‘s fee: putting coin in dead person’s mouth to pay
for ferry across Styx.
Strangers to be given precedence over man at home.

Duke permits visiting duke to go through narrow path
first. This sets custom. Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 515.

child: Couches provided for men of high rank.
Cuts of meat distributed according to rank.

The choicest portion assigned to the bravest at feasts. Irish myth:
Cross.

Rank among children recognized by quality of appointments
and food.
Precedence shown by position of shield (flag).
Long hair prized by Irish heroes.
Customs connected with eating and food.

Feast (hospitality) endures for three days and three
nights.

Feast (hospitality) endures for seven days and seven
nights.

content: Trumpet blown before house of one sentenced to death.
Touching head as sign of acceptance of bargain.
Greek: Iliad XXII 337 and passim; India: Thompson-Balys.

child: Duel: shooting and catching arrows in turn.

content: Newcomers forced to pass the night with ruling princess.

Given sleeping potion. Goods confiscated for failure to
consummate marriage. Italian Novella: Rotunda.
People weep when child is born.
They sing and laugh at burials. Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Pulling a man’s beard as an insult.
child: Fur made of beards of conquered kings.
Cutting off a man’s (woman‘s) hair as an insult.
Rubbing shaved head of hero with cow dung as insult.
Insult: lighting lamp with king’s moustache.

content: Woman veils self as expression of surprise.

child: Bells hung at every corner of ship.

content: Icelandic: Snorra Edda Skaldsk. XLI (Nibel), *Boberg; India: Thompson-Balys.
Injured husband will not kill a naked man.

Hero goes to encounter unarmed except for the arms he
wrests from his opponent. Irish myth: Cross.
Only the brave to wear beards.
Hero unwilling to answer questions before he is dressed.

child: Voyagers have right to ask landsman first question.
